num construction requirements prepare holes and installation of the chemical adhesive anchors in accordance with the manufacturers recommendations and instructions including weather and temperature limitations .
do not install chemical adhesive anchor systems before concrete attains its design strength .
num drilling of holes use drilling methods that do not cause concrete spalling or cracking or damage to the main reinforcing steel members .
drill the diameter and depth of the holes in accordance with the chemical adhesive anchor manufacturers instructions using drilling methods and drill bits specifically intended by the manufacturer for the particular anchorage .
repair spalled or damaged concrete as directed by the project manager .
do not drill with a lubricant water is not a lubricant .
maintain a distance of at least two num inches from the bottom of the structural slab to the bottom of drill holes .
only use anchor systems that can maintain this minimum surfacetodrill hole distance requirement and still meet certified strength requirements .
num hole preparation before installing the chemical adhesive anchors thoroughly clean holes by brushing with a metal or nylon brush and cleaning with water or air blasting .
ensure holes are dry before installing anchors .
diamond core drilling of the holes is not permitted .
num finishing after the contractor inserts the anchor into the full depth of the drilled hole the contractor shall strike flush the excess adhesive with the concrete surface .
after placing the anchors do not move anchors and do not load the anchors until adhesives are fully cured .

use anchor that attain the specified test loads without permanently displacing the anchor or damaging the concrete .
replace anchor devices that fail the load test .
test replaced anchors .

num hole preparation use impact drills equipped with carbide tipped bits or core drill .

section num pier and abutment bearing modification page num section num pier and abutment bearing modification num description this work shall consist of raising superstructure members slightly and modifying bearing units in substantial compliance with the pertinent portions of the standard specifications and the details shown on the plans or as directed by the project manager .
num materials all materials incorporated permanently into the work shall meet the requirements as shown on the plans .
num construction requirements loadcarrying superstructure members shall be slightly raised and temporarily supported by methods approved by the bridge engineer to permit modifications to be made to the designated bearing units .
unless the existing concrete deck has been removed all beams or girders in a span shall be simultaneously raised and supported .
bearing modifications shall be performed in a manner that will not damage any members being retained in the structure .
the bridge engineer shall approve proposed steel cutting and weld removal methods .
when shown on the plans traffic will be permitted to operate on the bridge or bridges during these operations .
unless otherwise provided painted area damaged by the work shall be cleaned and repainted as provided in section num recoating structures and section num safety and environmental requirements for paint operations .
no payment will be made for recoating damaged areas .

the work includes the following num .
scarifying the existing deck surface or pccp num .
removing loose and unsound concrete including concrete patching material num .
removing and replacing corroded reinforcing bars num .
other operations necessary to prepare deck or pccp for repair to the satisfaction of the project manager .
num materials num water provide water for cleaning and soaking the deck surface or pccp in accordance with section num water .
num construction requirements num equipment use equipment approved by the project manager as proposed by the contractor .
num surface preparation equipment use equipment that is mechanical or hydraulic in nature and that is able to remove surface concrete or unsound subsurface concrete without damage to sound material remaining part of the structure .
operate removal equipment in a manner satisfactory to the project manager .
num sawing equipment use sawing equipment capable of sawing concrete to the required depth .
num mechanical concrete removal equipment use mechanical equipment for scarification and removal of deteriorated concrete capable of uniformly scarifying or removing existing concrete to the required depth .
num sandblasting and shotblasting equipment use sandblasting or shotblasting equipment capable of removing rust and old concrete from exposed reinforcement .
the contractor may use highpressure water blasting if effective in removing unsound material .
num powerdriven hand tools use powerdriven hand tools for removal of concrete in conformance with the following limitations and having flat edged cutting points at least num inch wide .
use concrete chippers or breakers up to a nominal num lb class in full depth removal areas and for initial removal of deteriorated concrete located above the top mat of reinforcing steel .
if in the opinion of the project manager the use of such devices is detrimental to the integrity of the adjacent concrete deck slab discontinue their use and use removal devices up to a nominal num lb class .
section num bridge deck and pccp preparation for repair page num for chipping around reinforcement use removal devices up to a nominal num lb class .
use smaller chippers or breakers if the project manager believes the num pound tools are detrimental to the adjacent remaining material .
do not operate tools at an angle greater than num measured from the surface of the slab .
num hand tools use hand tools such as hammers and chisels as necessary for removal of final particles of unsound concrete .
num hydrodemolition hydrodemolition may be used for deck or pccp preparation upon approval by the state bridge engineer .
num preparation of surface num scarification uniformly scarify the top surfaces of existing decks or pccp as called for in the plans .
provide a scarified surface with a rough texture to promote bond to the concrete repair material .
scarify deck or pccp areas not accessible to the scarification machinery using approved chipping hammers or hand tools .
num deck sounding after scarification sound the deck or pccp under the direction of the project manager and mark areas of unacceptable concrete including full depth areas .
after removal of unsound concrete in accordance with section num resound and repeat process until all remaining concrete is sound .
blast clean only after the project manager approves the concrete deck area .
other methods of nondestructive evaluation may be proposed by the contractor for the sounding of the concrete .
proposed methods may only be used if approved by the state bridge engineer .
num deck preparation after scarification and deck sounding is complete remove unsound and deteriorated concrete in the marked areas in accordance with section num .
remove complete thickness of deck concrete at locations where less than num of the original deck or pccp thickness remain except in very isolated random locations as determined by the project manager .
remove unsound concrete to a depth that will provide a num inch minimum clearance around the reinforcing bars .
exercise care to prevent cutting stretching or otherwise damaging reinforcing bars and to prevent damage to sound concrete around reinforcement .
the department will not allow loads other than construction equipment on deck portions that have undergone concrete removal .
provide supports for the delivery trucks so the trucks do not drive directly on reinforcing bars in areas of partial or full depth repair .
securely fasten loose reinforcing bars to adjacent fixed bars with tie wire .
if the contractor uses hydrodemolition equipment the contractor shall take care to avoid the removal of sound concrete below the necessary depth .
num replacement of reinforcing bars replace existing reinforcing bars that are corroded or damaged to the extent that their structural integrity is in question .
section num bridge deck and pccp preparation for repair page num provide and install new bars of the same original size and remove the existing corroded or damaged bars .
blast clean corroded bars left in place to gray metal .
carefully flame cut or saw bars to be removed with minimal damage to adjacent material .
newly installed bars will have a num inch minimum clearance around their circumference .
lap reinforcing bars on each side of the damaged or removed area .
lap no .
num or smaller reinforcing bars at least num inch .
the project manager will determine the length of lap for larger reinforcing bars .
the contractor shall replace reinforcing bars damaged by the contractor at no additional cost to the department .
num cleaning of prepared deck and pccp surface clean deck and pccp surfaces to which the concrete is to bond using abrasive blasting or high pressure water blasting .
blast cleaning is sufficient to remove dirt oil concrete loosened by scarification and other deleterious material .
clean exposed reinforcing bars to gray metal and remove loose products of corrosion .
the contractor may leave tight flash rust occurring after blast cleaning .
clean surfaces with highpressure air blasting after blast cleaning .
wet deck surfaces and keep continuously wet but free of standing water for at least two num hours before and during placement of the overlay .
if it is necessary for the contractor to operate mechanized equipment on the cleaned surface before or during concrete placement the contractor shall temporarily cover the cleaned wetted deck surface with a layer of polyethylene film num mil or thicker .
num method of measurement the department will verify the measured quantities with the contractor daily .
deck preparation is measured after completion of deck scarification and deck sounding .
concrete used for repair will be paid for under the appropriate concrete pay item as specified in the plans .

num construction requirements section num concrete structure repair page num num preparation of repair areas the contract will specify approximate repair areas .
the contractor shall field verify locate and mark the precise areas of delamination and repair .
obtain project managers concurrence of work areas and establish pay quantities .
the contractor shall cut ¾ inch deep sawcuts around all repair areas prior to chipping andor other removal methods .
remove unsound material within the repair limits using chipping hammers or other approved handoperated devices .
num concrete removal saw cut all boundaries to num inch depth remove concrete with pavement breakers and chipping hammers .
use hand tools only for final removal of concrete from reinforcing bars and faces of remaining concrete .
use departmentapproved removal equipment .
the following restrictions apply to concrete removal tools num .
do not use pavement breakers heavier than the num lb class num .
do not use chipping hammers heavier than the num lb class num .
operate pavement breakers or mechanical chipping tools only at a num angle num .
use only handpowered tools such as hammers and chisels to remove the final concrete particles from reinforcing bars .
num concrete surface preparation and cleaning ensure the surface substrate is clean sound and dry .
remove substances that may prevent a bond between existing and new concrete .
if using acid etchers concrete cleaners or degreasers to clean the existing surface remove completely after cleaning .
mechanically roughen the existing surface using equipment such as chipping hammers .
remove loose and excess material from repair areas .
place a four num inch piece of duct tape every square yard to test for cleanliness .
the department will not allow more than num of the tape surface to show dust coverage .
before placing mortar or concrete clean repair areas with oilfree compressed air or pressurized water .
moisten the substrate and remove excess water .
num preparation of exposed reinforcing bars num bridge decks reinforced slabs on grade preserve existing reinforcing steel exposed during concrete removal chip at least num inch deep into the adjacent concrete around the entire bar in the removal area .
sandblast exposed reinforcing steel before placing new mortar or concrete .
strengthen corroded or damaged existing bars by splicing an equal sized bar at least two num ft longer than the corroded or damaged length .
the minimum splice length shall be one num ft on each end .
num other reinforced concrete repairs preserve existing reinforcing steel exposed during concrete removal .
if the bond between exposed bars and adjacent concrete breaks chip at least num inch deep into the adjacent concrete around the entire bar .
sandblast exposed reinforcing steel before placing new mortar or concrete .
section num concrete structure repair page num strengthen corroded or damaged existing bars by splicing an equal sized bar at least two num ft longer than the corroded or damaged length .
the minimum splice length shall be one num ft on each end .
num application of bonding agents use diluted bonding admixture or other manufacturerrecommended priming systems as bonding agents .
apply the bonding agents to the contact surfaces of the repair areas immediately before concrete or mortar placement .
num depth of repair use enriched mortar where the repair depth is less than one num inch and use enriched concrete where the repair depth is one num inch or greater .
if the repair depth is four num inches or greater use the appropriate class concrete or enriched concrete .
num forms for full depth repair provide forms to support concrete placed in the full depth repair areas .
the contractor may use wires from the reinforcing steel to suspend forms for areas up to five num ft num .
for larger areas the contractor may use the primary members of the superstructure to support the forms or shore them from below .
clean the concrete faces and reinforcing steel in areas of full depth repair as described previously .
num placing finishing and curing do not mix mortar and concrete in repair areas .
use forms if necessary .
num temperature and weather limitations make repairs when the air temperature is between num f and num f. maintain the temperature of the mortar and concrete at or above num f during the curing period .
use a set retardant if recommended by the manufacturer .
num placement place mortar or concrete in a continuous operation for each repair area .
for vertical surfaces start the work at the bottom of the patch and continue upwards and from one edge to the other to prevent the entrapment of air pockets .
if the repair area abuts or crosses a working joint place a temporary strip of waxed wood or premolded filler in the joint before placing repair material .
remove the strips before the concrete sets .
the contractor may also repair areas that occur on both sides of a joint by patching the entire cavity and restoring the joint by saw cutting immediately after the repair material has set instead of using a temporary vertical insert strip .
num curing cure in accordance with the manufacturers recommendations .
if the manufacturer does not specify a cure method use method num or method num in accordance with section num curing .
num inspection the project manager will examine repaired areas after the curing period is completed to ensure soundness of the repairs and complete bonding with the existing members .
remove and replace unacceptable areas at no additional cost to the department .

if the repair depth exceeds four num inches the department will negotiate a unit price with the contractor .
the department will measure exposed surfaces before the application of the special surface finish .

package components in separate containers .

section num epoxy injection page num num injection port materials injection ports are tubes fittings pressure plates or other devices used as entry points for the epoxy adhesive .
use suitable methods to scale each port after injecting epoxy at that port .
num temporary surface sealant use a temporary surface sealant to retain the injected epoxy adhesive .
the department will also allow pressure plates or other methods for retaining the epoxy adhesive .
num construction requirements num general perform the epoxy injection process in accordance with the manufacturers recommendations .
the department will mark cracks and delaminated areas for injection .
inject epoxy when concrete temperature is between num f and num f. inject epoxy continuously over the entire crack or area of delamination .
maintain low pumping pressures to prevent lifting the delamination .
num epoxy sampling during operations before starting injection work at hourly intervals during continuous injection work and when requested by the project manager take a numfluidounce sample of mixed epoxy from the injection device .
if the sample indicates improper proportioning or mixing of the epoxy the project manager will suspend injection work until the contractor corrects the problem .
num core sampling take core samples from injected cracks and delaminated areas and submit them to the project manager to verify penetration and bonding adequacy .
cut cores with a diameter of num num inch and to the full crack depth or six num inches whichever is smaller .
the project manager will specify core sample locations .
submit at least one num core sample for every num ft of injected crack or every num ftnum of injected delamination .
fill core holes with a departmentapproved epoxy mortar .
num equipment use positive displacing dispensing equipment that is capable of injecting epoxy at set pressures without pressure buildup .
where the contractor uses pressure plates to seal cracks the contractor shall use a special pressure fitting on the injection device to prevent leakage .
if the contractor drills out injection ports the contractor shall use drilling equipment with a vacuum system to remove and not compact drilling dust into cracks or delaminations .
num crack injection num crack preparation clean surface openings and crack interiors with oilfree compressed air to remove dirt dust silt and other materials .
if the department determines the result is inadequate use another cleaning method such as vacuuming pressure flushing routing or sawing .
if using section num epoxy injection page num pressure flushing blow water out with oilfree compressed air .
num injection ports unless the project manager approves other methods drill holes along the crack to insert the injection ports .
num temporary crack sealing temporarily seal surface openings of cracks between injection ports with material that can retain the epoxy adhesive during pressure injection and until the epoxy hardens .
num crack injection process when material travel is indicated the nozzle shall be moved to the port that shows epoxy and the pumped port sealed and this method continued until the crack is completely filled .
where vertical and horizontal cracks intersect inject the vertical crack below the intersection first .
on wide cracks where epoxy movement between ports will be rapid the contractor may pump two num or more ports simultaneously .
num rebonding delaminated areas by epoxy injection num injection ports use at least one num port for every square yard of delaminated areas .
num temporary sealing of delaminated openings temporarily seal the surface openings of cracks in the delaminated areas to prevent leakage of epoxy material .
num delamination injection process begin injection at one port near the perimeter of the delaminated area and continue until there is epoxy at an adjacent port .
then plug the port being pumped and continue the injection at the adjacent port showing epoxy .
continue this process until the entire delaminated area has been injected .
the contractor may pump two num or more ports simultaneously .
num finishing operations after curing is complete remove excess sealing material from the concrete surface without altering the concrete surface color or texture .
num loading restrictions do not allow traffic and other loads on the injected structures until the epoxy adhesive is solid .
num method of measurement the department will verify the measured quantities with the contractor daily .

num sequence of operations seal cracks on new concrete bridge decks or approach slabs after num days of curing .
apply penetrating water repellent treatment prior to crack sealing if specified in the contract .
num surface preparation clean concrete surfaces from three num inches to five num inches on either side of individual cracks .
remove asphalt material oil dirt rubber curing compounds paint and other deleterious materials by flooding sandblasting or shot blasting .
air blast with oil free compressed air or vacuum all loose material from visible cracks .
apply sealer when concrete surfaces and cracks are dry .
num storage of sealer store the sealer or its components separately and within the manufacturer recommended temperature ranges .
num application of sealer surface temperature shall comply with the minimum manufacturers recommendations .
follow the manufacturers mixing and application recommendations .
apply one num gal per section num crack sealing using lowviscosity gravityfed sealers page num num ft for crack sealing and one num gal per num ft num for surface sealing .
the department may require two num or more applications of sealer for cracks num inch or larger .
the department may require application of a temporary surface sealer to wider full depth deck cracks on the deck underside .
prior to use on the project ensure that the curing period recommended by the manufacturer confirms proper curing of the material .
num excess sealer sweep away sealer that does not fill cracks is not absorbed by the concrete surface and fills or partially fills the grooves of a tined or grooved surface .
num sand application apply dry silica sand with coverage of eight num lb per square yard .
place sand before the sealer starts to gel .
remove excess sand after the curing period .
num limitation of operations prevent the sealer from leaking through cracks onto persons traffic and property .
if deck preparation procedures or the sealer deface the appearance of bridge components other than the crack sealed areas repair those components at no additional cost to the department .

num mechanical application equipment use an epoxy or epoxy urethane distribution system that completely mixes the epoxy or epoxy urethane resin with hardening agent and provides a uniform distribution of the section num polymer concrete bridge deck overlay page num materials at the required application rate .
the use of hand held machine mixing equipment or hand mixing equipment is prohibited .
use a selfpropelled aggregate spreader that uniformly applies the dry aggregate at the manufacturers recommended application rate .
use an air compressor that produces oilfree and moisturefree compressed air to remove dust and loose material from the application surface before applying epoxy or epoxy urethane .
num hand application equipment use notched squeegees and brooms that spread the epoxy or epoxy urethane material in accordance with the manufacturers requirements .
periodically inspect squeegees during application for wear of the notch depth replace any defective squeegees .
use hand tools as necessary for placing the overlay .
num vacuum trucks use vacuum trucks that are clean and do not drip engine fluids or install drip pans to protect the clean deck and overlay .
num power brooms use power brooms that are clean and do not drip engine fluids or install drip pans to protect the clean deck and overlay .
num preconstruction num deck preparation complete deck repairs for patches delamination and crack filling before applying the overlay per section num concrete structure repair and section num epoxy injection as specified in the contract .
identify moist areas by taping an num inch num inch plastic sheet to the deck for at least two num h in accordance with astm d num .
if moisture appears on the bottom of the plastic sheet do not proceed with the overlay process .
use compressed air to dry the deck surface .
close and protect deck drains and areas of curb or railing above the proposed surface to ensure epoxy or epoxy urethane and aggregate does not pass through the drains .
num cleaning obtain project managers approval of bridge deck cleaning and preparation before placing the first course .
before placing the overlay clean the deck surface to remove materials that may interfere with bonding or curing .
the department will consider cleaning acceptable when the color of the concrete and mortar changes and coarse aggregate particles are exposed .
cleaning shall open the pores of sound mortar .
the department will consider pavement markings clean when exposed aggregate shows through the markings .
use a vacuum cleaner or air compressor to remove dust and other loose material .
do not use brooms .
num safety provisions use personnel certified in the safe handling of materials in accordance with the manufacturers requirements .
submit written documentation of material handlers training to section num polymer concrete bridge deck overlay page num the project manager before applying the overlay .

num temperature limitations follow the manufacturers deck temperature recommendations .
do not use artificial methods to raise the deck temperature .
follow the manufacturers temperature requirements for epoxy or epoxy urethane and aggregate components .
the contractor shall not apply epoxy or epoxy urethane for the following reasons num .
the contractor expects the air temperature to drop below the manufacturerrequired temperature within eight num h after application or num .
the epoxy or epoxy urethanes gel time is less than ten num min .
num usage limitations do not overlay bridges constructed with unventilated stayinplace forms unless forms are ventilated at a minimum rate of num square inch for every square foot or on pcc that is less than num days of age with polymer concrete overlay .
additionally manufacturers recommendations concerning moisture content must be followed .
num application materials shall be applied using mechanical metering mixing and distribution machinery as recommended by the manufacturer of the overlay system .
components a and b shall be applied within the temperature range recommended by the manufacturer .
broadcasting on concrete shall be performed in accordance with the manufacturers directions and the method approved by the project manager .
apply the overlay as two num separate applications with a total coverage of at least num gal per num ft² .
apply the first application of polymer at a rate of at least num gal per num ft² .
cover with a minimum of ten num pounds of aggregate per square yard or enough to completely cover the epoxy or epoxy urethane .
apply the second application of polymer at a rate of at least five num gal per num ft² .
cover with at least num pounds of aggregate per square yard or enough to completely cover the epoxy or epoxy urethane .
remove and replace first applications that do not receive enough aggregate before the polymer gels at no additional cost to the department .
the department will allow second applications not covered with enough aggregate to remain in place but the contractor must apply additional applications before opening to traffic at no additional cost to the department .
num curing no vehicular traffic or equipment shall be allowed on the overlay during the curing period .
cure each application of overlay polymer and aggregate free from vehicular traffic as recommended by the manufacturer and approved by the project manager and until a vacuuming or broom does not tear or damage the surface .
after the first application cures remove loose aggregate with a vacuum or broom then apply the second application .

remove the bond breakers num .
score the polymer before gelling or num .

no spalling scaling cracking or delamination is acceptable during the warranty period as defined by the following num .
spalling .
broken or missing pieces of concrete overlay num .
scaling .
the bridge deck overlay surface has a visible exposed rough surface texture resulting from a loss of aggregate or mortar num .
delamination .
there is visible or audible debonding of the concrete bridge deck overlay from the existing bridge deck surface num .
cracking .
any visible crack .
at the end of each yearly evaluation period the department will provide the contractor with a report that describes occurrences of spalling scaling cracking or delamination .
the department will perform an annual skid in accordance with aashto t num .
for the warranty period an average skid number of num or higher is acceptable .

finishing machines shall be operated normal to the longitudinal bridge or roadway centerline .

num trial batches and trial overlay mix one num or more trial batches of polyester concrete for various percentages of resin binder according to manufacturers recommendations .
the approximate percentage of polyester resin binder to use will be determined from the trial batches .

num application before applying the prime coat the concrete area to receive the prime coat shall be dry when tested according to astm d num .
the concrete surface temperature shall be between num degrees f and num degrees f during application of the prime coat .
follow the manufacturers deck temperature recommendations .
do not use artificial methods to raise the deck temperature .
follow the manufacturers temperature requirements for polyester resin and aggregate components .
the contractor shall not apply polyester resin if either of the following conditions exists num .
the air temperature is expected to drop below the manufacturerrequired temperature within num h after application or num .
the polyester resin gel time is less than ten num min .
the prime coat shall be uniformly applied to completely cover the surface to receive the polyester concrete .
apply the prime coat at an approximate rate of num to num galydnum prior to placement of polymer concrete .
flood concrete surfaces with the prime coat allowing penetration into the concrete and filling of all cracks .
redistribute the applied prime coat in cracks by squeegees or brooms .
the quantity of initiated promoted resin shall be no more than what is needed to apply a prime coat .
a noticeable increase in viscosity prior to placement will be cause for rejection .
if the primed surface becomes contaminated or if there is a failure of the material clean the contaminated or failed area by abrasive blasting and re prime .
immediately after the prime coat has been applied the polyester concrete overlay shall be placed in accordance with manufacturers guidelines .
mix polyester concrete in mechanically operated mixers .
use a sufficient amount of initiator in the polyester concrete to produce set times between num and num minutes after placement .
accelerators or inhibitors may be required to achieve proper set times and shall be used as recommended by the resin supplier .
place and finish polyester concrete before gelling or within num minutes following addition of the initiator whichever occurs first .
discard polyester concrete not placed within this time .
use finishing equipment that strikes off the polyester concrete to the established grade cross section and nominal depth .
fit finishing equipment with vibrators or other means of consolidating the overlay material .
construct longitudinal joints parallel to the roadway alignment at the approved locations .
construct vertical joints perpendicular to the deck surface .
section num polyester concrete bridge deck overlay page num the smoothness of the polyester concrete surface will be tested with a straightedge .
the surface shall not vary by more than num feet from the lower edge of a num foot num feet long straightedge placed in any direction .
any surface that fails to conform to the above tolerance shall be ground to meet this requirement .
apply abrasive sand finish to polyester concrete surfaces .
the sand shall be commercial quality blast sand conforming to the absorption capacity and moisture content requirements of polymer concrete aggregate of this specification .
provide sand such that num shall pass the no .
num sieve and num shall be retained on the no .
num sieve .
apply the sand finish by mechanical means immediately after overlay strikeoff .
broadcast sand uniformly onto the surface before gelling occurs at a minimum rate of num lbyd num .
after application of the sand finish and before gelling occurs texture the overlay by grooving with a steeltined rake with tines num inch wide and spaced from ¾ inch to num½ inch apart .
groove to a depth of num to num inch .
the surface texture of the overlay shall be uniform and shall have a coefficient of friction of not less than num .
if the coefficient of friction is less than num grind or groove parallel to the centerline those portions of surfaces until the coefficient of friction requirement is met .
num curing protect the finished overlay from moisture equipment and public traffic until the overlay achieves an average schmidt hammer reading of num .
the schmidt hammer test shall consist of the average of ten num readings strikes all taken in an area approximately num inches in diameter .
perform one num such test per num sq ft of overlay .
traffic may be allowed on the overlay when the reading of num is achieved .
do not contaminate concrete surfaces during cleanup of tools and equipment .
do not dump or spill polyester concrete materials or cleaning solvents in areas that will cause environmental or fire hazards .
num testing provide the necessary equipment and supplies for conducting adhesion tests on the completed overlay .
perform adhesion tests according to aci numr appendix a of the aci manual of concrete practice .
adhesion tests shall obtain a num psi minimum pulloff or cohesive failure within existing concrete .
perform tests at a frequency of one num test per every num sq ft of deck surface in a random location .
prime and patch test holes with polyester concrete immediately after testing .
num corrective work correct surface variations that exceed num ft per num ft unless otherwise directed by the project manager .
repair damaged overlay areas by saw cutting in rectangular sections to the top of the concrete surface and replacing the material at no additional cost to the department .
in the event that the testing performed under num does not meet minimum pulloff the material shall be removed and replaced in the areas in which low adhesion is determined from additional testing .
any additional testing required shall be incidental to the work .

num .
scaling the concrete overlay surface has a visible exposed rough surface texture resulting from a loss of aggregate or resin .
num .
delamination visible or audible debonding of the polyester concrete bridge deck overlay at the bond line with the existing concrete surface .
num .
cracking any visible crack not reflected from a crack in the existing concrete .

for the warranty period an average skid test number of num or higher is acceptable .

num method of measurement polyester concrete will be measured by the cubic yard .
the volume to be paid for will be determined from calculations based on the quantity of resin binder used the percent by weight of resin binder in the polyester concrete and a unit weight of num pcf .
the contractor shall furnish suitable measuring devices to assure correct proportioning of materials and accurate measurement for calculating payment quantities .
the payment quantity shall be the calculated quantity of polyester concrete used in the work exclusive of material used in trial overlay and any wasted or unused material .
payment quantity will include patches .
the contract price paid per cubic yard for polyester concrete shall include full compensation for furnishing all labor materials tools equipment and incidentals and for doing all the work involved in placing polyester concrete including furnishing methacrylate resin prime coat and furnishing materials for trail overlays removal of unsound concrete and preparation of repair areas when polyester concrete is used as the patching material and as shown on the plans as specified in the standard specifications and as directed by the project manager .
removal of loose concrete and preparation of repair areas for patching material other than polyester concrete will be measured by the square yard in accordance with section num concrete structure repair .
num basis of payment the accepted quantities measured as provided above will be paid for at the contract price per unit of measurement for the pay items listed below that are shown in the proposal .
payment will be full compensation for the work described in this section .
pay item pay unit polyester concrete bridge deck overlay cubic yard num work included in payment the following work and items will be considered as included in the payment for polyester concrete and will not be measured or paid for separately a. icri concrete surface profile chips and b .
removal of unsound concrete and preparation of repair areas when polyester concrete is used as the patching material .

num epoxycoated reinforcing coating num epoxy coating thickness section num steel reinforcement page num the thickness of the epoxy coating after curing shall be between seven num mils and num mils .
for acceptance at least num percent of all recorded film thickness measurements shall be in this range .
num continuity of epoxy coating ensure that the coating is free from holes voids contamination cracks and damaged areas .
use a numvolt holiday detector in the production line to continuously check the coated bar for holidays .
ensure that there are no more than an average of one num holiday per linear foot of coated bar .

num construction requirements num general measure dimensions from centerline of bar to centerline of bar .
store all reinforcing bars above ground on platform skids or other supports .
reinforcing shall be kept free from dirt grease and other foreign matter .
reinforcing shall be kept free of corrosion as far as practicable .
num bar lists and bending diagram when the contract documents do not include detail bar lists and bending diagrams the contractor shall provide such list and diagrams to the state bridge engineer for review and approval .
the approval of bar lists and bending diagrams shall in no way relieve the contractor of responsibility for correctness .
the bar lists and bending diagrams shall meet the requirements of the current edition of the concrete reinforcing steel institutes csri publication reinforcing bar detailing .
the contractor shall allow num days for review of the submittal .
num bundling and tagging tag and mark reinforcement bar shipments in accordance with csris code of standard practice .
num bar bending the department will allow cold bending around a pin .
do not field bend grade num bars epoxycoated bars or hotdip galvanized bars .
unless otherwise directed ensure the bend diameter is in accordance with table num .
that table specifies minimum pin diameters for uncoated and coated bars .
section num steel reinforcement page num table num minimum diameter of bends minimum pin diameter bar diameters type of reinforcement coated bars size uncoated bars coated bars stirrups and ties num num num num main reinforcement num num num num all types num num num num all types num num num num all types num num num num num splicing splice bars only in accordance with the plans unless otherwise approved by the state bridge engineer .

the department will allow mechanical couplers for aashto m num grade num and astm anum grade num deformed bar if the splice strength verified by tests is greater than or equal to num of the yield strength of the spliced reinforcing bars and develops the specified tensile strength of the bars .
aci num type num mechanical couplers meet the above splice strength requirements .
submit documentation to the state bridge engineer showing where mechanical couplers are proposed to be used what type of coupler manufacturer and model number will be used and certified test results from an approved testing service showing that the couplers meet these requirements .
show splice locations and coupler clearance dimensions in the request and submit before fabricating the reinforcing bars that will be coupled .
allow at least two num weeks for review and approval .
unless otherwise specified ensure that welded wire fabric and barmat reinforcement overlap is at least one num spacing of cross wires plus two num inches when measured between the outermost cross wires of each sheet .
num field cutting bars may be cut to length in the field by shearing or sawing .
flame cutting will not be permitted .
the ends of coated or clad bars cut in the field shall be patched with suitable patching material .
num reinforcing bar placement place reinforcing bars as shown in the contract drawings securely tied in position with wire not smaller than num gauge .
carefully place support and tie reinforcing and place and consolidate concrete around reinforcing with care to avoid any displacement and damage to the coatings .
tie all intersections where bar spacing is greater than or equal to one num ft in either direction .
tie alternate intersections where bar spacing is less than one num ft in either direction .
use metal spacers chairs hangers and other approved devices to hold the reinforcing bars in position .
when using concrete blocks to support the bottom mat of reinforcement in slabs that are cast on ground use dense rectangular concrete blocks that section num steel reinforcement page num num .
have compressive strength and density equal to or greater than the concrete to be placed num .
occupy a small area and num .
contain embedded plastic or epoxycoated tie wires for attachment of reinforcement .
do not use wooden spacers or supports .
tie reinforcing bar mats in bridge deck and concrete box culvert slabs to beams and forms to prevent upward movement during concrete placement .
ensure that the space between ties does not exceed ten num ft. num reinforcing bar placement tolerances ensure that the space between adjacent bars does not vary more than the greater of ½ inch or num num of the spacing dimension shown on the plans .
except for slabs cast on the ground ensure that the clear cover of reinforcement shall not vary more than the greater of either num inch or num of the dimension shown on the plans .
ensure that the reinforcement clear cover in slabs cast on the ground does not vary more than minus num inch from the position shown on the plans .
num cleaning reinforcing bars before placing concrete clean the reinforcing bars of materials that would reduce or destroy the bond .
num welding of reinforcing steel weld reinforcing steel only if the contract requires it or if the state bridge engineer authorizes it in writing .
weld in accordance with aws specification dnum reinforcing steel welding code .
welding of bars other than astm anum is allowed only upon approval of qualified welding procedures for those bars that comply with aws dnum .
submit a welding procedure specification stamped by an aws certified welding inspector for each procedure .
welding to other added contractor steel for stiffening cage alignment lifting handling and other contractor needs shall not be welded to reinforcing steel called for in the plans .
num concrete cover requirements concrete cover is the distance from the surface of concrete to the edge of the bar nearest to that surface .
if cover dimensions are not specified in the contract use the concrete cover dimensions in accordance with table num concrete cover requirements .
table num concrete cover requirements location minimum cover inch concrete cast against and permanently exposed to the ground num concrete exposed to the ground or weather principal reinforcement num stirrups ties and spirals num num concrete bridge slabs top reinforcement num bottom reinforcement num concrete not exposed to weather or in contact with ground principal reinforcement num ½ section num steel reinforcement page num table num concrete cover requirements stirrups ties and spirals num bar bundles num a aor equal to the diameter of a single bar of equivalent area whichever is greater .
num final inspection do not place concrete until the department inspects the reinforcing steel in place .
acceptance of the reinforcing steel does not relieve the contractor of responsibility for the cover and position control of the steel .
num requirements for epoxycoated reinforcing bars num storage and handling of epoxy coated reinforcing bars transport and store epoxycoated reinforcing steel on wooden or padded supports .
use devices with padded contact areas to handle epoxycoated reinforcement bars and prevent bartobar abrasion .
do not drop or drag bars or bundles .
use spreader beams and multiple pick points when hoisting bar bundles to prevent sagging .
do not store epoxycoated reinforcing bars in sunlight for more than num days .
use only nonmetallic sleeved heads with immersiontype vibrators when placing concrete around epoxycoated reinforcing .
num repair of damaged epoxycoating repair visible damage before shipping .
ensure the total surface area of patched coating material is not more than one percent num of the total coated area in any one num foot section .
the department will reject bars shipped to the project that show more than one percent num patched coating material .
patch sheared ends cuts and exposed areas promptly before detrimental oxidation occurs .
keep exposed areas free of contaminants before patching .
patch coating damage before placing concrete .
ensure that the total patched surface area does not exceed two percent num of the coated area in any one num foot section .
the department will reject any installed bars with more than two percent num patching .
apply the patching material in strict compliance with the manufacturers instructions .
allow adequate time for the patch to cure before placing concrete over the bars .
num requirements for galvanized reinforcing bars num galvanizing bent bars where galvanized bars are detailed to be bent or have other types of coldforming the bars must be bent before galvanizing .
num surface preparations prepare bar surfaces by removing dirt and grease with a hot alkaline solution .
use a diluted solution of sulfuric acid to pickle .
use a solution of zinc ammonium chloride to flux .
ensure that the resulting surface condition is about equal to sspcsp num as described by the sspc .
num thickness of galvanizing ensure that the galvanizing after drying with air steam or wiping is from three num mils to num mils thick .
determine the thickness with a magnetic thickness gage .
section num steel reinforcement page num num chromating treat the galvanized coating with chromate .
this prevents a reaction between the bars and fresh portland cement paste .
the department will allow proprietary chromating treatment solutions of equivalent strength instead of the generic chemical treatment in accordance with astm a num section num .
quenching of bent bars or bars to be bent is not allowed .
such bars must be chromated at ambient temperature .
num finish and adherence of coating ensure that the zinc coating is free of bare spots blisters flux spots or inclusions dross and acid or black spots .
the department will reject bars that stick together after galvanizing .
a matte gray finish appearance is not by itself a cause for rejection .
ensure that the coating can not be removed through normal handling .
num installation of galvanized reinforcing bars transport and store galvanized bars in a manner to prevent damage to the galvanized coating .
all systems for handling galvanized coated bars shall have padded contact areas .
all bundles of bars shall be lifted using spreader beams and multiple pick points or a platform bridge to prevent bartobar abrasion from sagging in the bar bundle .
the bars and bundles shall not be dropped or dragged on the ground platforms or other bars .
galvanized reinforcing bars shall not be tied with black steel or left in contact with black steel .
galvanized reinforcing bars shall be left in contact only with galvanized plasticcoated or epoxycoated surfaces .
num repair of damaged galvanizing patch sheared ends cuts and exposed areas using a zincrich paint .
prepare the surface to be patched so that it is clean dry and free of oil grease and corrosion products .
blastclean the surface to nearwhite metal in accordance with sspcspnum .
spray or brushapply the paint containing the zinc dust as recommended by the manufacturer in one num application of as many passes as required to achieve a dry film thickness of four num mils as determined using a magnetic or electromagnetic gage .
num repair of stainless steel clad deformed steel bars the stainless steel clad deformed steel bars shall be shop bent as shown on the contract documents .
all ends of the bars where mild steel core is exposed shall be capped by one num of the following methods num .
heat shrink cap applied in accordance with the cap manufacturers instructions .
num .
neoprene cap adhered with silicone or epoxy sealant .
num .
stainless steel cap epoxied in place .
num .
stainless steel seal weld .
no field cutting or bending of stainless steel clad deformed steel bars will be allowed .
num method of measurement the department will measure reinforcing bar weight in accordance with table num nominal dimensions of reinforcement whether it is black steel epoxycoated galvanized stainless steel stainless steel clad or lowcarbon chrome steel .
the computed weights of reinforcing bars will be based on the nominal weights of the bars before application of the epoxycoating or galvanizing of the bars .
when splice overlaps are unscheduled or are made for the convenience of the contractor and are approved by the state bridge engineer at locations not shown in the contract the extra steel required for splice overlaps will not be included in computing the weight of the bars for payment .

g num guidelines for design for constructability although the aashtoaws steel collaboration documents are titled guidelines or guide specifications consider them to have the same importance and standing as a code or a specification .
if the content of the collaboration documents appears permissive with words such as should could may etc .
consider the content to be a requirement unless otherwise approved by the department .
in the event of a conflict between a referenced code and this specification this specification will take precedence .

num attachment and fit of gussets and stiffeners where welding of gusset plates stiffeners or other secondary attachments to main structural members would otherwise result in intersections of welds clip back the corners of the attachments num num inch minimum from the corner in each direction to avoid such intersections .
terminate welds attaching secondary components to main members num inch short of the end of the attachments .
if the plans require bearing stiffeners finished to bear mill or grind the ends and obtain an even bearing against the flange the stiffeners will bear on .
if the plans require tight fit stiffeners fit the stiffeners tight against the flange to exclude water after being coated .
num straightening of flanges at pier bearings abutment bearings and splices straighten girder or beam flanges perpendicular to the webs .
at bearings straighten flanges before fitting stiffeners .
at splices straighten flanges before coating and shipment .
do not cold bend .
num bearing plates pins and rollers num sole masonry and shoe plates flatten the top and bottom surfaces of sole masonry and shoe plates to within num inch .
machine sole plate surfaces that will contact elastomeric bearing pads perpendicular to the direction of expansion .
machine other expansion surfaces in the direction of expansion .
num pins and rollers accurately turn pins and rollers to dimensions and ensure that they are smooth straight and free of flaws .
num pin holes bore a two num inch diameter hole longitudinally through the center of pins with an eight num inch diameter or larger .
bore pinholes true to the specified diameter smooth and straight at right angles to the axis of the member and parallel with each other unless otherwise required .
produce the final surface with a finishing cut .
do not vary the outside to outside distance of end holes in tension members and inside to inside distance of end holes in compression members by more than num inch .
bore holes in builtup members after shop assembly .
num threads section num steel structures page num ensure that bolt and pin threads are in accordance with unified standard series unc ansi bnum class numa for external threads and class numb for internal threads .
thread pin ends with a diameter of num num inch or greater with six num threads per inch .
num surface finish finish the surfaces of bearings base plates pins rollers and other bearing steel that will come into contact with each other or with concrete in accordance with ansi bnum surface roughness waviness and lay .
num connections num welding num welder qualifications use annually certified welders or those who provide documentation demonstrating continuing experience in the process .
welder must be qualified for the position the weld is performed in .
num testing of complete penetration welds conduct nondestructive qc radiographic testing on complete penetration welds in accordance with aws dnum or dnum as applicable .
the department may allow ultrasonic testing as a substitute for radiography .
submit an ultrasonic testing plan for approval at least num days before the start of fabrication .
provide detailed information about the fabricators previous experience with ultrasonic testing and resumes showing the training and experience of persons performing the testing .
do not use ultrasonic testing for cases described in section num of the bridge welding code .
num bolted connections bolt with high strength bolts in accordance with section num highstrength bolts .
make bolt holes num inch larger than the nominal diameter of the connector unless otherwise specified .
num gaps between ends of abutting members where the contract requires abutting milled joints ensure there are no gaps .
face the ends to provide a full and even bearing when assembled .
where the contract requires close joints do not exceed num inch between the ends of abutting members .
do not exceed num inch between abutting ends of girders at splices .
num camber verification verify girder camber during the laydown operation .
unless assembling girders in the horizontal position meet the total camber dimensions less the deflections produced by the weight of the girder .
num erection requirements erect the structure in accordance with aashtonsba steel bridge collaboration s num steel bridge erection guide specification .
num acceptance mark the department will stamp fabricated members at the fabrication facility upon acceptance .
do not use any piece that does not bear the acceptance stamp .
section num steel structures page num num placement of bearings ensure that column bases and bearing devices bear fully and uniformly on substructures .
do not place bearings on pier or abutment bridge seat areas that are improperly finished or irregular .
grout to achieve uniform bearing only when the contract allows grouting .
place masonry plates and beam and girder span pedestals on impregnated fabric pads approved by the project manager at least num inch thick .
num anchor bolt holes core drill anchor boltholes in accordance with table num required nominal anchor bolt hole diameters .
table num required nominal anchor bolt hole diameters bolt diameter inch hole diameter inch num num num num num num num num num set anchor bolts using nonshrink grout from the departments approved products list .
remove excess mortar after the grout has set .
ensure that anchor bolt washers and nuts bear evenly against the steelbearing surface .
ensure anchor bolts at the expansion ends of spans allow the free movement of the span .
num field bolting install high strength bolts in accordance with section num highstrength bolts .
block main structural members to the desired camber before torquing the bolted splice connections .
for skewed steel bridges with diaphragms perpendicular to the longitudinal centerline finger tighten diaphragm attachment bolts before deck placement .
fully torque bolts after the deck slab is in place .
following completion of the superstructure and after priming fill open holes in exterior beams and girders with button head bolts before final acceptance .

num method of measurement if structural members are specified by a nominal unit weight the department will calculate weight based on the nominal weights and dimensions .
when structural members are not designated by a nominal unit weight the department will calculate weight using the unit weights listed in table num metal unit weights for measurement .
the department will deduct the weight of copes cuts bevels and open holes from the gross weight .
the department will not make deductions for bolt holes .

num nuts provide nuts in accordance with aashto m num astm a num with dimensions in accordance with ansi b num and table num dimensions of highstrength bolts .
section num highstrength bolts page num ensure plain ungalvanized nuts are of grades num c d or cnum with a minimum rockwell b hardness of num or brinell hardness of num or heattreated grades numh dh or dhnum .
provide heattreated galvanized nuts graded numh dh or dhnum .
provide mechanically galvanized nuts in accordance with aashto m num class num .
overtap nuts before galvanizing .
overtap so the nut will assemble freely on the coated bolt in accordance with aashto m num astm a num .
lubricate galvanized nuts with a dyed lubricant of a color that contrasts with the galvanizing color .
num washers provide washers in accordance with aashto m num astm f num .
use flat circular hardened washers in accordance with table num circular washer dimensions and table num washer tolerances .
use square or rectangular beveled washers that taper in thickness in accordance with table num square or rectangular beveled washers for american standard beams and channels and table num washer tolerances .
where necessary to provide a proper fit clip washers on one num side no closer than ⅞ of the bolt diameter from the center of the washer .

num testing of assemblies provide the manufacturers or distributors rotational capacity test results on bolt nut and washer assemblies .
use washers in the test even if washers are not used in the assembly on the project .
test each combination of bolt production lot nut lot and washer lot as an assembly .
unless required by the installation procedures do not include washers in the lot identification .
assign a rotational capacity lot number to each lot combination tested .
the minimum testing frequency is two num assemblies per rotational capacity lot .
num procedure for rotational capacity tests for long bolts test bolts long enough to test in a tension calibrator in accordance with the following procedures num .
mark the calibrator face plate with lines at vertical and at num num and num num of a turn clockwise from vertical num .
use a calibrated torque wrench num .
use spacers with a hole size no larger than num inch larger than the bolt to be tested num .
mount the bolt calibrator on a steel frame or section such as a flange or a cross frame .
num .
put the nut on the bolt .
measure from the end of the threaded shank to the underside of the bolt head when there are num to num full threads of the bolt between the bearing face of the nut and the bolt head num .
put the bolt in the tension calibrator and install the required number of shim plates and washers needed to produce the measurement from step num always install one num washer under the nut num .
snug tighten the bolt with a hand wrench to the tension listed in table num snug tight tension do not exceed two num kips more than that value section num highstrength bolts page num table num snug tight tension bolt diameter in installation tension minimum kip num num num num num num ⅞ num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num .
match mark the nut to the vertical line on the bolt calibrator faceplate num .
using the calibrated manual torque wrench tighten the bolt to at least the tension listed in table num installation tension .
measure and record the torque and the tension generated simultaneously with that torque .
measure torque with the nut in motion table num installation tension bolt diameter in snug tension minimum kip num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num .
calculate the torque in accordance with the following equation num d t v num where v is the calculated torque value t is the measured tension in pounds d is the bolt diameter in feet record the calculated value .
the measured torque values must equal or be less than the calculated torque .
assemblies with measured torque values exceeding this calculated value fail the test .
num .
for assemblies passing step num further tighten the bolt to the rotation listed in table num required rotation .
measure the rotation from the vertical line to the initial match marking in step num .
record the bolt tension .
table num required rotation bolt length l measured in step num required rotation turns section num highstrength bolts page num table num required rotation bolt length l measured in step num required rotation turns l numd num numd l numd num l numd num num note d bolt diameter .
assemblies that fail before completing the required rotation by stripping or fracture fail the test .
bolt tension measured at the required rotation must equal or exceed the values in table num minimum tension requirements .
assemblies that do not meet this tension fail .
table num minimum tension requirements bolt diameter in tension minimum kip num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num num .
loosen and remove nut and examine the threads on the nut and bolt .
assemblies showing evidence of thread shear failure stripping or torsion failure fail .
num procedure for rotational capacity test for short bolts test bolts that are too short for a tension calibrator in accordance with these procedures equipment requirements num .
a calibrated torque wrench and a spud wrench num .
spacers with a hole size no larger than num inch greater than the tested bolt num .
a steel section with a normal size hole to install bolt .
any available splice hole with plate thicknesses that will provide the number of threads under the nut required in step num of the following procedures is acceptable .
the procedure is as follows num mark the steel section with lines at vertical and at num num and num num of a turn clockwise from vertical num put the nut on the bolt .
measure the bolt length and the distance from the end of the threaded shank to the underside of the bolt head when there are three num to five num full threads of the bolt between the bearing face of the nut and the bolt head .
num .
put the bolt in the hole and install the required number of shim plates to produce the thread stickout measured in step num .
always install one num washer under the nut .
num .
snug using a hand wrench .
do not exceed num of the torque determined in step num of this procedure .

match mark the nut to the vertical line on the steel section .
num .
tighten the bolt using the torque wrench by turning the nut to the rotation listed in table num initial required rotation .
use a second wrench to prevent bolt head rotation during tightening .
record the torque required to reach this rotation .
measure torque with the nut in motion .

indicate the steel melting and manufacture location in the mtr .

results of all other required tests and num .
